In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During  a  country  programming  mission  in  December  2008,  the  Government  of  the 
People's Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
capacity development technical assistance (TA) to help  the Yunnan provincial government 
develop a low-carbon economy in Yunnan Province. The TA was included in ADB's 2009 non-
lending pipeline for the PRC.1 The fact-finding mission was fielded during 21–24 October 2009. 
This report is based on the memorandum of understanding achieved with the government 
during the fact-finding mission on the impact, outcome, detailed scope of works, cost estimates, 
financing plan, key activities, and implementation arrangements of the TA. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The PRC is the world’s second largest energy consumer after the United States and has 
one of the world's fastest growing energy sectors. While energy fuels economic growth and 
poverty reduction, inefficient energy use accelerates resource depletion and severely damages 
the  environment.  It  is  hard  to  reconcile  continued  energy  consumption  growth  with 
environmental  sustainability.  With  a  strong  political  commitment  towards  improving  energy 
efficiency, the government has articulated a clear vision as reflected in its target of quadrupling 
gross domestic product (GDP) per capita while only doubling energy use during 2000–2020.  
 
3.  The PRC government has made great efforts to reduce carbon dioxide (CO ) emissions 
2
and  improve  energy  efficiency.  Its  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan,  2006–2010  mandates  a  20% 
reduction  in  energy  intensity2 by  2010,  which  has  been  allocated  to  the  provinces  and 
municipalities by the government. Ten key industries have been identified for energy savings, 
and 1,000 enterprises that intensively use energy are now under tight supervision. Meanwhile, 
the government has adopted a series of incentives, including energy-efficiency funding and 
financial  incentives,  and  actively  pursued  industrial  structural  adjustment,  technological 
upgrading,  improved  demand-side  management,  and  decommissioning  inefficient  facilities. 
Despite these efforts, energy intensity reduced relatively slowly in 2006 by 1.79%, 2007 by 
3.66%, and 2008 by 4.59%, leaving heavier challenges for the remaining years of the plan, 
2009–2010.  Barriers  to  energy  efficiency  include  shortcomings  in  the  dissemination  of 
information on technology and incentives and in the capacity of local government entities and 
officials. 
 
4.  The PRC is making efforts to address global climate change. The carbon intensity3 of the 
national economy has declined in the past 2 decades. According to International Energy Agency, 
from 1990 to 2004, the PRC's carbon intensity fell by 49.5%. But there is still a very large scope 
to further reduce the carbon intensity by (i) promoting a more diversified energy mix to reduce 
reliance on carbon intensive fossil fuels,4 and (ii) consistently improve energy intensity to bring it 
at par with other developed economies such as Japan and the United States.5 In 2006, the 
Government  initially  planned  to  develop  a  low-carbon  economy  in  the  National  Evaluation 
Report on Climate Change. In 2007, the Government declared that the PRC would promote a 
low-carbon economy by improving energy efficiency, developing low-carbon energy technology,

2   
expanding carbon sinks,6 and developing renewable energy.7 More recently in November 2009, 
the PRC has announced to reduce carbon intensity of its GDP in 2020 by 40%-45% compared 
with  2005  level.8 These  have  been  recognized  as  strong  political  commitments  by  the 
government to develop a low-carbon economy. However, as low-carbon economy is very new to 
the PRC, corresponding strategies and polices are required to promote it at different levels.  
 
5.  Yunnan is a southwestern province of the PRC, and like others, has experienced robust 
economic growth over the past 2 decades. In 2008, its GDP was CNY570 billion, 11% higher 
than in 2007. However, its GDP per capita in 2008 was only CNY12,547, or 60% of the national 
average. 9 Yunnan's  economic  development  has  been  energy-intensive.  Its  total  energy 
consumption in 2008 amounted to 76 million tons of coal equivalent (tce), up by 5.92% from 
2007. In 2008, its coal consumption was 79.5 million tons, up by 2.53% from 2007. In the same 
period, Yunnan's energy-intensity was 1.562 tce per CNY10,000, or 1.42 times the national 
average,  ranking  Yunnan  21st  among  30  provinces  and  municipalities.10 Rapid  industrial 
development and urbanization in Yunnan have caused serious pollution and environmental 
degradation. In 2008, Yunnan's emissions were 501,700 tons of sulfur dioxide, down by 6.0% 
from 2007; 831.6 billion cubic meters of flue gas, up by 2.9% from 2007; 280,500 tons of 
chemical oxygen demand, down by 3.29% from 2007; and 79.86 million tons of industrial solid 
waste, up by 12.5% from 2007. Among these four indicators, only sulfur dioxide emission 
reduction  achieved  the  national  average.  It  is  expected  that  1%  of  energy  efficiency 
enhancement can reduce 1.5 million tons of CO  emissions in Yunnan Province. 
2
 
6.  The  Yunnan  provincial  government  (YPG)  has  recognized  that  the  current  energy-
intensive development path is neither economically desirable nor environmentally sustainable 
and is considering a transition to a low-carbon one. However, it faces several challenges for 
lack of (i) capacity or familiarity with international best practices to improve energy efficiency;   (ii) 
investment  or  suitable  financing  instruments;  (iii)  energy  conservation  awareness  among 
industrial enterprises, which do not see much incentive to save energy; or (iv) a comprehensive 
development  strategy  that  could  guide  it  toward  balancing  economic  development  and 
environmental protection. Based on successful energy efficiency improvement interventions in 
other large energy intensive provinces, ADB is well positioned to provide such assistance to 
help  the  YPG  comprehensively  analyze  these  issues  and  recommend  a  low-carbon 
development strategy.11  
 
7.  Kunming, the capital of Yunnan Province, currently contributes 28.2% of provincial GDP 
and  30.2%  of  provincial  industrial  production.12 In  2006,  five  energy-intensive  industries 
consumed 8.1 million tce and accounted for 85% of energy consumption in Kunming. These five 
energy-intensive industries are (i) iron and steel, consuming 3.09 million tce and accounting for 
33.7% of total energy consumption in Kunming; (ii) power generation, 1.61 million tce and

11.4%; and (v) non-ferrous metals, 0.87 million tce and 9.5%.13 As a logical first step to address

Kunming, allowing the lessons in Kunming to be replicated in other cities in Yunnan. 
 
8.  In Strategy 2020,14 ADB identified energy as a core operational sector and achieving 
environmental sustainability as a priority. ADB has introduced new initiatives to augment its 
assistance  to  developing  member  countries  for  acquiring  low-carbon  technologies  and 
implementing  energy  efficiency  projects.  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  the  PRC15 
emphasizes balanced and sustainable growth with more efficient use of resources and more 
stringent protection of the environment. One of the key priorities of the Eleventh Five-Year Plan 
is to improve energy efficiency by 20%, which is a flagship program of the PRC to address 
climate change and environmental challenges arising from rapid economic growth. The TA is a 
close fit with ADB and PRC priorities. 
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The impact of the TA will be enhanced energy security with lower CO  emissions in 
2
Yunnan  Province.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  the  improved  capacity  of  provincial 
governmental agencies in developing a low-carbon economy.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The successful implementation of the TA is expected to deliver three outputs:  
 
(i)   an  investigation  of  energy  consumption,  energy  efficiency,  and  the 
potential  to  reduce  CO   emissions  from  the  five  energy-intensive 
2
industries  of  iron  and  steel,  power  generation,  chemicals,  building 
materials, and non-ferrous metals;  
(ii)   a draft strategy and prioritized action plan to enhance energy efficiency 
and reduce emissions; and 
(iii)   training and information dissemination.  
 
11.  For  output  1,  consultants  will  review  the  status  of  energy  consumption  by  the  five 
energy-intensive  industries  and  the  existing  structural,  policy,  organizational,  and  financing 
setup of the selected industries. For output 2, the consultants will estimate the potential for 
saving  energy  and  reducing  CO   emissions  from  the  five  energy-intensive  industries  and 
2
compare  them  with  international  and  national  standards.  Based  on  these  analyses,  the 
consultants will develop an applicable strategy and prioritized action plan to enhance energy 
efficiency  and  reduce  emissions  to  promote  low-carbon  energy  development  in  Yunnan 
Province. For output 3, the consultants will introduce international and national experience in 
related areas and evaluate its relevance to Yunnan. The consultants will present their findings in 
workshops and organize training. Lessons in Kunming will be summarized and disseminated to 
other cities in Yunnan.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 equivalent, of which $400,000 equivalent will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Climate Change Fund.16 YPG will finance the balance of the 
cost, equivalent to $100,000, in the form of office accommodation, logistics, and remuneration of 
counterpart staff. The Government assured the fact-finding mission that counterpart services, 
facilities,  and  funds  would  be  available  as  required  according  to  the  TA  implementation 
schedule. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The  YPG  will  be  the  executing  agency,  and  the  Yunnan  Provincial  Environmental 
Protection  Department  (YEPD)  will  be  the  implementing  agency.  The  YEPD  has  already 
designated  officials  to  manage  the  TA  and  help  coordinate  other  governmental  agencies. 
Consulting firms will be invited to submit simplified technical proposals, and a consulting firm will 
be engaged using quality- and cost-based selection at a ratio of 80:20 in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Two international 
consultants (an energy specialist and an energy economist for 4 person-months combined) and 
six  national  consultants  (two  energy  specialists,  two  energy  economists,  an  environment 
specialist, and a training specialist for 25 person-months combined) are the estimated needs. 
Similar expertise is required of international and national consultants in their respective areas. 
The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
14.  Training, seminars, and workshops will be administered through consulting services. 
Consultants are expected to provide training materials, and important topics will be highlighted 
during workshops and seminars. Consultants are required to summarize seminars, workshops, 
and training results and report to the YPG and ADB. Office equipment financed under the TA 
will  be  procured  through  the  YPG  using  the  shopping  method  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  equipment  will  be 
transferred  to  the  YPG  after  TA  completion.  To  facilitate  TA  implementation,  an  advance 
payment  facility  is  requested,  and  TA  funds  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook.17 Wherever  necessary,  external  resource 
persons will be hired to provide specific training to a diverse group of industries and end users.   
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 16 months from December 2009 to April 2011. The 
consultants will be required to submit (i) an inception report within 1 month after signing the 
consulting contract, (ii) a midterm report 6 months after signing the consulting contract, (iii) a 
draft final report 1 month before TA completion, and (iv) a final report within 1 month after 
receiving feedback from ADB and the YPG on the draft final report. All reports will be written in 
English and translated into Chinese. Progress reports will address the terms of reference with 
details appropriate to that stage of the TA. The consultants will maintain close working relations 
with ADB and the YPG. Tripartite meetings of ADB staff, the YPG, and the consultants will be 
held periodically to provide guidance to the consultants and review their reports.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People's Republic of China for Developing a Low-Carbon Economy in 
Yunnan Province, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Technical assistance (TA) to the People's Republic of China for Developing a Low-
Carbon Economy in Yunnan Province will be implemented in consultation with the Ministry of 
Finance (MOF), Department of Finance of Yunnan Province, Yunnan Provincial Development 
and Reform Commission, and Yunnan Provincial Environmental Protection Department.  
 
2.  Consulting firms will be invited to submit simplified technical proposals, and a consulting 
firm will be engaged using quality- and cost-based selection at a ratio of 80:20 in accordance 
with Asian Development Bank (ADB) Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time). Two international consultants (an energy specialist and an energy economist 
for 4 person-months combined) and six national consultants (two energy specialists, two energy 
economists, an environment specialist, and a training specialist for 25 person-months combined) 
are the estimated needs. Similar expertise is required of international and national consultants 
in their respective areas. The outline of terms of reference for consultants are listed as follows. 
 
A.  Consultants 
 
3.  Energy specialists (international 2 person-months, national 12 person-months). The 
energy specialists will contribute mainly to outputs 1 and 2. One of the energy specialists will be 
the team leader and  
 
(i)  lead the preparation and delivery of TA outputs, as guided by ADB and the 
Yunnan Provincial Government; 
(ii)  review  the  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan  targets  and  disaggregated  targets  for 
Yunnan for improving energy efficiency and reducing emissions; 
(iii)  review  the  status  of  energy  consumption  in  the  selected  energy-intensive 
industries of iron and steel, power generation, chemicals, building materials, and 
non-ferrous metals; identify investigation methods; and prepare an investigation 
plan; 
(iv)  analyze the selected industries, review their production technologies and energy 
efficiency,  and  compare  them  with  corresponding  international  and  national 
energy efficiency benchmarks;

(viii)  estimate the potential for saving energy in the selected industries based on

(ix)  estimate the potential to reduce CO  emissions from the selected industries;

8.  All TA deliverables and progress reports will be written in English. National consultants 
will be responsible for translating documents into Chinese. Three copies of each TA deliverable
